stem: A 19-year-old client with a comminuted femur fracture is 24 hours post-injury. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two relevant parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory and neurological decline in a trauma patient.
Background: Femur fracture from high-velocity impact. Traction applied.
Assessment: Client is increasingly confused and 'combative.' Oxygen saturation is decreasing despite 4L nasal cannula.
Recommendation: Evaluate for Fat Embolism Syndrome.

tabs.title: Orthopedic & Pulmonary Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Skin ExamFine, red petechial rash over chest and axillaHallmark Sign
Mental StatusRestless; Disoriented to placePossible Cerebral Embolization
Chest X-ray'Snowstorm' infiltrates notedPossible Acute Lung Injury
Oxygen Saturation84% (Critical)Hypoxemia

actionOptions.text: Administer high-flow oxygen via non-rebreather mask.
Ensure strict immobilization of the fractured extremity.
Instruct the client to perform leg exercises.

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate, SpO2, and lung sounds.
Neurological status and presence of petechiae.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs and symptoms of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) (c2), which can occur following long-bone fractures. The classic triad includes respiratory distress (SpO2 84%), neurological decline (confusion), and petechial rash. Priority nursing actions include administering high-flow oxygen (a1) and ensuring immobilization of the fractured extremity (a2) to minimize further embolization. Monitoring should focus on respiratory status (p1) and neurological/skin changes (p2).
clinicalPearls: Treatment for FES is primarily supportive.
The 'snowstorm' pattern on chest x-ray indicates lung inflammation due to fatty acids.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming this is a standard pulmonary embolism and selecting Heparin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Heparin is used for blood clots, not fat emboli. The presence of a petechial rash in a patient with a recent long-bone fracture is a key indicator of FES.

mnemonic.title: FES Triad
mnemonic.expansion: F - Fat in Lungs (Dyspnea), E - Encephalopathy (Confusion), S - Skin Spots (Petechiae)
